properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning Saturday evening. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow and strong winds are expected to spread across parts of New Brunswick late on Saturday. There is still a fair amount of uncertainty on the exact track of this developing low pressure system. The snow may change briefly over to ice pellets or freezing rain over central parts of the province. Snowfall warnings may be issued as this system draws nearer. Conditions will improve on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T00:32:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T08:33:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1832489826.2020
Area: Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts near 60 mm expected Friday and Friday night. A slow moving front over the area will cause rain to intensify Friday morning and continue most of Friday night. About 30 mm of rain is expected to fall on Friday and a further 30 mm Friday night before easing in the early morning hours of Saturday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T20:27:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T04:28:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0398041027.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected on already saturated ground. Total rainfall: 40 to 60 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday evening until Monday morning. Remarks: Rain is expected to begin Saturday and may become heavy, at times, over some areas overnight. There is still some uncertainty with the exact track of this developing low pressure system. Rain may become mixed at times with snow near Fredericton. Strong northeasterlies will also accompany the precipitation this weekend. Rainfall warnings may be issued on Friday afternoon. The rain will taper off by Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T00:34:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T08:35:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2464835638.2020
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Fundy National Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Very strong winds, with the potential for gusts to 100 km/h this morning, will maintain blizzard conditions for today and tonight. Blizzard conditions will end Saturday morning as winds start to diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T01:26:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T09:27:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4052459731.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong winds and blizzard conditions. As winds become more westerly, wind gusts to 70 km/h will bring reduced visibilities and blizzard conditions this morning. Blizzard conditions will end later this morning as winds start to diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions continue tonight and Friday morning.. Strong winds gusting up to 70 km/h tonight, with up to 10 to 15 cm of fresh snow is producing blizzard conditions. The blizzard will continue tonight and end Friday morning as winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to widespread poor visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds and blizzard conditions for Sachs Harbour tonight and Friday. Blowing snow with winds gusting up to 80 km/h overnight tonight, combined with 5 to 10 cm of fresh snow are producing blizzard conditions. The blizzard is forecast to continue through Friday afternoon, and end when winds diminish late in the day on Friday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T20:37:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T04:38:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1102885112.2020
Area: Sachs Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong easterly winds will whip up the snow and produce blizzard conditions today. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds are forecast to develop in the Iqaluit area early this evening. Winds gusting to 90 km/h are expected giving reduced visibilities at times in blowing snow. Winds will gradually moderate overnight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T12:47:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T20:48:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3660814220.2020
Area: Iqaluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will develop over the Eastern US Seaboard on Saturday. It will affect Central Quebec beginning Saturday evening, then reach Eastern Quebec on Sunday. This storm may bring significant snowfall amounts, strong winds, widespread blowing snow, and even freezing rain. Although it is still too early to forecast with certainty how much snow will fall and what areas will be hardest hit, the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula could see up to 30 centimetres of snow. Freezing rain should mainly affect the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula. These poor weather conditions may have a significant impact on travel. Be prepared for changing road conditions that could deteriorate rapidly in heavy snow and blowing snow. Future weather statements will provide more details as the low pressure system's track as well as precipitation types and amounts become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T01:45:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T09:46:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4105159204.2020
